title: R42741
content: The Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) Program offers private health insurance to federal employees, retirees, and their dependents, providing over $40 billion in benefits annually. Participation is voluntary, with about 85% of employees and 90% of retirees enrolled. Coverage options include individual, family, and self plus one plans starting in 2016. Coverage options for eligible individuals in the FEHB Program include individual, family, and self plus one plans. Plans are either fee-for-service (FFS) or health maintenance organizations (HMOs), with premiums shared between the federal government and the employee or retiree. All plans cover basic services like hospital and physician care, with varying benefits and cost-sharing requirements. Prior to the creation of FEHB in 1959, federal employees could not obtain health insurance through the federal government. Instead, they had to purchase coverage voluntarily or through union and employee association plans. In 1950, private sector employers started offering health insurance to their employees, with some covering a portion of the premiums. President Truman's Commission recommended federal government health insurance in 1951. Congress passed the Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (FEHBA) to provide health insurance for federal employees. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (FEHBA) established parameters for health insurance coverage for federal employees, including eligibility, types of plans, and government's share of premiums. It also created an Employees Health Benefits Fund and outlined the role of the Office of Personnel Management (OPM). The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (FEHBA) established an Employees Health Benefits Fund to pay for program expenses and outlined the role of the Office of Personnel Management (OPM). OPM has the authority to contract with insurers and manage FEHB. The general model of FEHB allows enrollees to choose coverage from competing private insurers, with employees and retirees sharing the cost of premiums with the federal government. Many amendments have been made to FEHBA since its passage. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (FEHBA) established the Employees Health Benefits Fund and outlined OPM's role in managing FEHB. Enrollees can choose coverage from private insurers, with costs shared between employees, retirees, and the government. While some aspects of FEHB have remained consistent, changes have been made to the government's share of premiums, eligibility, services, and benefits. Congress plays a role in modifying FEHB through proposing changes or reacting to them. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (FEHBA) established the Employees Health Benefits Fund and outlined OPM's role in managing FEHB. Enrollees can choose coverage from private insurers, with costs shared between employees, retirees, and the government. Changes have been made to the government's share of premiums, eligibility, services, and benefits, with Congress playing a role in modifying FEHB. Policymakers and researchers have been interested in FEHB as a model for health insurance programs and expanding coverage. The FEHB model consists of competing insurers providing coverage to enrollees with minimal intervention from OPM. The FEHB model, established in 1959, allows enrollees to choose coverage from private insurers with costs shared between employees, retirees, and the government. It is viewed as successful in giving enrollees cost-conscious choices and constraining overall cost growth. Researchers have explored exporting aspects of the FEHB model to other health care programs like Medicare, expanding access to FEHB, or creating new programs modeled after FEHB to provide coverage to individuals not federal workers or retirees. Some policymakers and researchers have considered exporting aspects of the successful FEHB model to other health care programs like Medicare. They have also explored expanding access to FEHB or creating new programs modeled after FEHB to provide coverage to individuals outside of federal workers or retirees, such as small business employees or the uninsured. Legislation has been introduced to create new programs or expand FEHB eligibility. Additionally, it has been suggested that certain features of FEHB could serve as a good model for state-level health insurance exchanges, and lessons learned from FEHB may be instructive for establishing these exchanges at the state and federal levels. Some have suggested that features of FEHB could be a model for state health insurance exchanges. Congressional interest in FEHB extends beyond its applicability as a model, as policymakers have a responsibility for its viability and sustainability. Congress has a financial interest in the program. The report discusses how Congress has influenced the evolution of the Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) program by conditioning federal funds on policy changes, adjusting the government's share of FEHB premiums, modifying program eligibility, and implementing policies affecting the relationship between Medicare and FEHB.
